DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China Commerce Ministry said that China filed a complaint to WTO regarding the US proposed tariff list on USD 200bln worth of Chinese goods. In related news, the US challenged China, EU, Canada, Mexico and Turkey for “illegal tariffs”, while there were also reports that Mexico said it will take defensive actions and respond to US trade measures. (Newswires)

New Zealand REINZ House Sales (Jun) Y/Y -1.6% (Prev. 1.3%). (Newswires)
 

UK

UK government spokesperson earlier confirmed the acceptance of Brexiteer/ERG amendments that were consistent with policy, in which the amendments included no NI customs border, no fast track capacity to form customs union, leaving EU VAT regime and limiting capacity to collect tariff revenue for EU without reciprocity. However, some Conservative MPs were said to vote against the government because of anger that ministers have given into Brexiteers, while UK Defence Procurement Minister Guto Bebb has resigned due to ERG amendments. (Newswires)

Notable Cross Border Tax Bill Amendment Votes:

- UK House of Commons voted (316 to 289) against New Clause 11 of the Cross Border Tax Bill which would have made establishing tariff free access to the EU as a negotiating objective for the UK Government.
- UK House of Commons voted (316 to 36) against New Clause 16 which would have required approval from Scottish Parliament to implement some of the powers in the Bill.

- UK House of Commons voted (305 to 302) to approve New Clause 36 which prevents the UK collecting taxes on behalf of another territory or country, unless this were done on a reciprocal basis.
- UK House of Commons voted (303 to 300) to approve Amendment 73 which commits the Government to having a separate VAT system to the EU.

 

COMMODITIES

US Secretary of State Pompeo said they could grant Iran waivers for some ‘small’ transactions, while US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US will consider exemptions in specific cases if countries are not able to reduce Iranian oil purchases to zero to meet the sanction deadlines. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump is said to have raised meddling in the US elections with Russian President Putin, in which the latter reiterated Russia did not meddle in US politics, while Putin also commented that Russia and the US could work together to regulate international energy markets. (Newswires)
 

US

Fed's Kashkari (non-voter, dove) said policymakers are focused on the flattening of the yield curve and that he is unsure whether the flattening yield curve signals a recession ahead. Furthermore, Kashkari stated that Fed is risking inverting the yield curve by continuing to hike and that there is little reason to raise rates further since doing so could trigger a recession. (Newswires)

US Retail Sales MM Jun 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.8%, Rev. 1.3%).
US Retail Sales Ex-Autos MM Jun 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.9%, Rev. 1.4%)
US Retail Inventories Ex-Auto Rev May 0.1% (Prev. 0.1%)
US Business Inventories MM May 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.3%)
 

MARKET RECAP

BlackRock (BLK) reported beats on revenue and EPS, and said it saw $20bln of net inflows in Q2; CEO also said he aims to return $26bln to shareholders in the next year. Bank of America (BAC) also beat on both EPS and revenue, supported by loan growth, lower expenses, smaller tax rates. Trading revenues were up by nearly 7% to USD 3.596bln. J.B. Hunt (JBHT) also beat on both top- and bottom-lines. After the market close, numbers from Netflix (NFLX) will be published. Biotech names have been hit, mainly gene editing companies, following a new study which found the DNA damage from CRISPR Therapeutics (CRSPR) was seriously underestimated, which hit: CRSP, Editas Medicine (EDIT) and Intellia Therapeutics (NTLA); Crispr did pare back some of the losses, before resuming its slide, after they denied they used the methods described in the study since they were not relevant to their plans. Tesla (TSLA) closed red following a controversial tweet from CEO Elon Musk about the diver who rescued the Thai children stuck in a cave, who is now considering filing action against Musk. Boeing (BA) was higher amid various reports of orders from the Farnborough Air Show. Goldman Sachs (GS) is reportedly close to announcing David Solomon as the new CEO, which could come as soon as Tuesday. Hasbro (HAS) was hit by a downgrade at BMO, UPS (UPS) was higher after an upgrade at UBS. Amazon (AMZN) was up as its Prime Day gets underway, though did see some negative ticks in late trade on reports of a tech glitch. VF Corporation (VFC) was boosted after an upgrade at JPMorgan. The energy sector fared the worst, tracking the slide in crude prices. Financial names were up after strong earnings from Bank of America (BAC), however, Blackrock (BLK) was weak despite top- and bottom-line beats. SPX -0.12% at 2797.96, NDX -0.24% at 7357.90, DJI +0.17% at 25061.89.

Yields were higher across the curve in thin volume, with the curve modestly bear-steepening at settlement, which was 2s10s rise by just shy of 1bps, but still within the 25bps handle. Short-dated yields rose to highs not seen in almost a decade ahead of Tuesday’s testimony by Fed chair Powell (See below for preview). There was little by way of major moves in Treasuries after retail sales data, however, losses appeared to be scaling back in afternoon trade as equities, and more noticeably, oil found selling action. US 10YR T-notes futures (U8) settled 6 ticks lower at 120-05+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 16th July 2018 - Crude crushed on fears of a supply ramp
content:
To download the report, please click here. If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries down, oil down, dollar down.
* REAR-VIEW: Oil crushed as supply returns; Trump criticised after Putin meeting; US retaliates after China WTO complaint; Kashkari warns Fed hikes could trigger recession.
* COMING-UP: Fed chair Powell testimony to Senate; Tuesday’s BMO earnings UNH, JNJ, GS, PGR, PLD, SCHW; Tuesday AMC earnings KMI, TMUS; RBA minutes; UK jobs data; BOE’s Carney.

* TRUMP-PUTIN MEETING: While there was little new information out of the Trump/Putin meeting, aside from the platitudes about closer cooperation and efforts towards global peace, two items have captured the media narrative. 1) Trump was asked to condemn alleged Russian meddling in the US Presidential election, which he did not do, instead taking aim at Hillary Clinton’s missing email servers. 2) Putin was asked whether he wanted US President Trump to win the election, to which he did, though denied Russia meddled. The lack of criticism by Trump against Putin is reinforcing his opponents’ view that the US President is somehow in the pocket of Russia, and in wake of the joint press conference, Trump was accused by talking heads of putting politics over national needs. Even influential GOP lawmakers (speaker Ryan, Sen Cornyn, Sen Flake, Sen Lindsey, Sen Burr) also added to the criticism, though ultimately, the market reaction was muted.

* TRADE: China’s MOFCOM filed a complaint at the WTO over US President Trump’s proposed tariffs on $200bln of Chinese goods, following up on last week’s promise that it would immediately complain to the WTO over US unilateralism. Shortly after, the US responded, challenging five WTO members individually (China, EU, Canada, Mexico, Turkey) over what it said was “illegal [retaliatory] tariffs”. Trade Representative Lighthizer said that the US’ steel and aluminium tariffs were justified under international agreements, but the retaliatory measures from other countries in response were not.

* US RETAIL SALES: June’s retail sales data was in line with expectations, though there were some upward revisions to May’s data. The headline came in 0.5% MM, in line with the consensus; while the control group – which the BEA uses in its consumption spending calculation – was unchanged at 0.4%; also in line with expectations. “The 12-month change in control group (and total) sales remains near its post-recession high-water mark. None of the rises or falls in the underlying series seem to reflect a pull forward from possible trade war effects,” UBS said.

* FED: Fed’s Kashkari (non-voter, dove) said Fed policymakers are focused on the flattening yield curve, and although he was unsure about whether the narrowing signals a recession ahead, he warned that the Fed risks triggering a recession by potentially inverting the yield curve, adding that there is little reason to raise rates further.

* WTI (Q8) SETTLES -$2.95 AT $68.06; BRENT (U8) SETTLES -$3.49 AT $71.85. Crude was hammered, with concerns that a supply glut could return, as US considers exemptions from Iran sanctions, while refineries and ports around the globe begin coming back online. Additionally, renewed chatter in recent days of a possible release from the US Strategic Petroleum Reserve in the US ahead of the midterm elections was adding to worries of greater supply.

* RETURNING SUPPLY: Libya’s Sharara field (capacity 290k BPD) was said to be pumping 130k BPD (it was under 100k BPD at the end of last week, after the abduction of workers), its Waha oil field has restarted production at a 20k BPD rate, and the El-Feel field has risen to 70k BPD, according to reports. In Iraq, the Umm Qasr port was expected to be fully operational on Monday or Tuesday, according to officials, after the port was hit by civil unrest in the Sourthern oil-producing regions of the country. In Europe, Equinor is not expecting escalation of strike action to meaningfully hit output in the short-term.

* IRAN SANCTIONS: Iran Oil Minister says OPEC decision does not give members the right to raise their production level above targets. US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said there will be no blanket waivers on Iran sanctions, but the US will consider exemptions in certain cases if countries cannot reduce on Iran oil purchases to zero. Mnuchin emphasised that the US wants to be careful in the wind-down around energy markets as it reimposes sanctions on Iran. Mnuchin will discuss Iran sanctions with counterparts at G20 this week.

* CRUDE INVENTORY POLL: This week, analysts are forecasting US crude stocks will draw down by 4.5mln barrels, distillates +1.2mln, gasoline -0.8mln. Stocks at the Cushing hub are seen lower by 368k (from 10/Jul) and lower by 1.3mln (from 6/Jul).  

* SPX -0.12% at 2797.96, NDX -0.24% at 7357.90, DJI +0.17% at 25061.89. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: +0.10%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.51%, Energy: -1.25%, Financials: +1.40, Health Care: -0.65%, Industrials: -0.46%, Materials: -0.68%, Telecoms: +0.45%, Tech: -0.31%, Utilities: -0.11%.

* EARNINGS: BlackRock (BLK) report beats on revenue and EPS, and said it saw $20bln of net inflows in Q2; CEO also said he aims to return $26bln to shareholders in the next year. Bank of America (BAC) also beat on both EPS and revenue, supported by loan growth, lower expenses, smaller tax rates. Trading revenues were up by nearly 7% to USD 3.596bln. J.B. Hunt (JBHT) also beat on both top- and bottom-lines. After the market close, numbers from Netflix (NFLX) will be published.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Biotech names have been hit, mainly gene editing companies, following a new study which found the DNA damage from CRISPR Therapeutics (CRSPR) was seriously underestimated, which hit: CRSP, Editas Medicine (EDIT) and Intellia Therapeutics (NTLA); Crispr did pare back some of the losses, before resuming its slide, after they denied they used the methods described in the study since they were not relevant to their plans. Tesla (TSLA) closed red following a controversial tweet from CEO Elon Musk about the diver who rescued the Thai children stuck in a cave, who is now considering filing action against Musk. Boeing (BA) was higher amid various reports of orders from the Farnborough Air Show. Goldman Sachs (GS) is reportedly close to announcing David Solomon as the new CEO, which could come as soon as Tuesday. Hasbro (HAS) was hit by a downgrade at BMO, UPS (UPS) was higher after an upgrade at UBS. Amazon (AMZN) was up as its Prime Day gets underway, though did see some negative ticks in late trade on reports of a tech glitch. VF Corporation (VFC) was boosted after an upgrade at JPMorgan. The energy sector fared the worst, tracking the slide in crude prices. Financial names were up after strong earnings from Bank of America (BAC), however, Blackrock (BLK) was weak despite top- and bottom-line beats.

* M&A: CNBC sources said Comcast (CMCSA) is highly unlikely to make another bid for Fox’s (FOXA) assets and will instead focus on a bid for Sky (SKY LN). Disney (DIS) then said Fox may not choose to increase its offer for Sky. The $3.9bln acquisition of Tribune Media (TRCO) by Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) came under fire after FCC chairman said he has serious concerns about the deal and that he would put the transaction through a lengthy administrative process, which is often seen as a ‘deal killer’. Apollo (APO) and other private equity firms expressed interest in acquiring engineering company Arconic (ARNC) in a deal that could be worth more than $10bln.

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (U8) SETTLE 6 TICKS LOWER AT 120-05+. Yields were higher across the curve in thin volume, with the curve modestly bear-steepening at settlement, which was 2s10s rise by just shy of 1bps, but still within the 25bps handle. Short-dated yields rose to highs not seen in almost a decade ahead of Tuesday’s testimony by Fed chair Powell (See below for preview). There was little by way of major moves in Treasuries after retail sales data, however, losses appeared to be scaling back in afternoon trade as equities, and more noticeably, oil found selling action.

* DXY: The greenback is softer ahead of Tuesday’s testimony by Fed chair Powell, with profit taking cited after the buck posted its best week in a month last week. There was some mild buying after retail sales data. The EUR was stronger against the USD, JPY and GBP, and pops its head above the 1.17 handle

* GBP: Cable started the week on the front-foot, but still couldn’t manage to break above the 1.33 handle; in afternoon trade, Brexit headlines once again slapped the pound around, after reports that the government was to accept all of the Brexiteers amendments to the Cross-Border Trade Bill, leaving scope for a harder Brexit; The news sent GBP back down to the key support at 1.3220, while EURGBP jumped to over 0.8850. There are concerns that the government will face defeat in Monday’s vote with the pro-EU lawmakers in the Conservative Party unhappy that UK PM May conceded to the Brexiteers.

* CHF: Trading in yen has been somewhat subdued on account of the Japanese being away for Marine Day, leaving CHF to receive attention as the haven-FX; the Swissy strengthened on Monday, reminding traders that the march-up in EURCHF will face challenges, with recent snap-backs on trade news flow reiterating the importance of the Franc as a hedge against trade wars. 1.1650 is the immediate support beneath.

* AUD: Ahead of the RBA meeting minutes overnight (and labour market data due Thursday), the Aussie is trading flat against the buck, with higher US yields and weakness in copper and crude giving the pair a slight downside bias. The consensus seems to expect the RBA to retain a cautious tone in its minutes (brief preview below). Traders will also be looking to the central bank’s comments on AUD funding after noting in its minutes that overall global financial conditions remain expansionary.  

* COMING-UP – POWELL TESTIMONY: Fed Chair Powell Dual-Testimony to the US Senate (Tues, July 17) and the US House (Weds, July 18) Fed’s Jerome Powell – who since his appointment as chair, has generally tended to avoid rocking the boat in his public addresses – will be testifying in his capacity as Fed chair, so will likely repeat the themes from the June FOMC meeting minutes; Powell will likely give a nod to the Fed’s current economic and rate projections, which look for two more rate rises in 2018, as the Fed normalises policy gradually. Click here for full briefing.

* COMING-UP – RBA MINUTES: RBA’s meeting minutes from its July meeting will be released on Tuesday, and the minutes aren’t expected to contain any significant new information. At the meeting, the Reserve Bank kept policy on hold, with the bank concerned about the state of international trade, subdued domestic wage growth, as well as tightening credit conditions within Australia. After the RBA remove the phrase that the next move is “likely up” in its June meeting minutes, some are now questioning the notion whether the next rate move is up. “For now, RBA comments suggest the hurdle to ease is still high, but if our 'credit tightening' deteriorates into a ' credit crunch' scenario then we think the RBA would likely cut,” UBS opines.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: retail revisions revive flagging Dollar
content:
DXY

The index and broad Usd got a lift on the back of early US data, or to be precise decent revisions to May retail sales figures that embellished in line numbers for last month and offset a disappointing control group reading that will feed into GDP (flat vs +0.4%). The DXY has rebounded from sub-94.500 lows and just below a series of downside tech levels, including 94.770 (50% Fib), 94.458 and 94.431 (10 and 30 DMAs respectively).

CHF/NZD

Vying for top G10 spot, as the Franc rebounds further from recent lows vs the Usd and Eur, to circa 0.9970 and 1.1680 vs 1.0068 (new ytd base set last Friday) and 1.1700+ on a combination of profit taking/short covering and technical retracement. The Kiwi has nudged closer to 0.6900 ahead of Q2 CPI data later that is forecast to show headline inflation picking up in Q2 on a y/y basis (1.60% from 1.1% previously).

EUR/GBP

The next best majors heading in to the close of Monday’s EU session, but off earlier highs vs the Greenback on the aforementioned data-related buck bounce. The single currency has slipped back from 1.1725 towards the big figure where the top of layered option expiry interest rolled off (3.2 bn from 1.1650-1.1700), along with just over 1 bn in the Gbp cross at the 0.8800 strike. Cable also slipped back after topping out just ahead of 1.3300 and with attention now switching to the UK parliament debate/vote on the Customs Bill amidst more reports that the Government may concede on all ERG amendments. Chart-wise, the pair is right near resistance around 1.3260-63 (30 DMA and 61.8% Fib), while 1.3236 (10 DMA) may provide some support if the 1.3225 is retested.

CAD

Choppy trade for the Loonie as crude prices slumped again, but Usd/Cad has drifted down towards 1.3100 vs circa 1.3160 at one stage with the aid of strong Canadian existing home sales (up 4.1% m/m vs -0.1% previously).

AUD/JPY

Relative underperformers as Aud/Usd remains capped below 0.7450 and the Nzd cross tests 1.0950 vs 1.0975 at one stage overnight, and with the Aud focus now turning to RBA minutes to the July policy meeting tomorrow, with guidance tweaked towards a more neutral stance and the outlook for growth, inflation and wages still skewed towards downside risks. Usd/Jpy is still rangy between 112.20-55 as the headline pair eyes a key 76.4% Fib around 112.33 and the return of Japanese markets on Tuesday after the long holiday weekend.

subject: Additional US Equity Stories - GE, MSFT
content:
• General Electric (GE)/Microsoft (MSFT) – The two have entered into the largest partnership to date, accelerating Industrial IoT adoption for customers. (Newswires)
  • Conduent (CNDT) – The co. wins a contract worth more than USD 1bln with Global Fortune 50 companies and plans to hire 1000 people to fill the positions. (Newswires)
  • Microsoft (MSFT) – The co. announced an IA collaboration with National Geographic. (Newswires)
  • Boeing (BA)/Embraer (ERJ) – The two names are expecting regulatory approval for the planned Boeing’s acquisition of Embraer’s commercial aircraft division for USD 4.75bln. (Newswires)
  • Praxair (PX) - Linde sells assets for USD 3.3bln to help get Praxair deal cleared. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) - British diver mulls legal action over Elon Musk's baseless 'pedo guy' claim. (CNBC)
  • Salesforce (CRM) – The co. entered not a definite agreement to acquire Datorama. (Newswires)
  • Sally Beauty (SBH) downgraded to Underperform on challenges at BofA/Merrill
  • PJT Partners (PJT) downgraded to Neutral on valuation at BofA/Merrill

subject: DEBT UPDATE: core bonds back off after early US data
content: Broadly firmer than expected US retail sales, including decent back data upgrades that compensated for a flat control group, have pushed Bunds and Gilts back to within striking distance of earlier lows for the day, while US Treasuries have slipped to fresh session troughs amidst reports of some block selling in 5 year note futures, but with the curve a bit steeper again.

RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 16th July - Earnings from BLK, BAC
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

16th July 2018

Earnings

  • BlackRock (BLK) Q2 Adj. EPS USD 6.66 vs. Exp. USD 6.60, revenue USD 3.61bln vs. Exp. USD 3.08bln. Reports USD 20bln of total net inflows in Q2. CEO said he is aiming to return USD 26bln to shareholders in next 12 months. (Newswires)
  • Bank of America Corp (BAC) Q2 EPS USD 0.63 vs. Exp. USD 0.57, revenue USD 22.6bln vs. Exp. USD 22.5bln. Results supported by loan growth, lower expenses, smaller tax rates. Trading revenues were up by nearly 7% to USD 3.596bln (from 3.369bln in Q2 2017). (Newswires)
  • J.B. Hunt (JBHT) Q2 EPS USD 1.37 vs. Exp. USD 1.28, revenue USD 2.14bln vs. Exp. USD 2.06bln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – Samsung patent over a system that monitors heart rate and blood pressure could rival the LED light technology that Apple uses in its watches. Separately, the tech giant has lost key sales executives due to struggling iPhone sales in India. (Business Insider)
  • Boeing (BA) – The aircraft manufacturer expressed concerns over tariff talks and over the influence it might have on its supplier costs, though it has not seen yet any impact on its business from US-China tensions. Separately, Jackson Square Aviation announced an order for 30 737 MAXs for a USD 3.5bln deal at FarnboroughAir Show , DHL Express announced the purchase of 14 777 freighters for a USD 4.7bln deal and Boeing also finalised the USD 1.7bln order for five 777 Freighters with Qatar airways signed at the air show. (Newswires)
  • Johnson &Johnson (JNJ) – The pharmaceutical announced it will appeal the USD 4.7bln verdict awarded to the women who claim its talc products gave them ovarian cancer, stating it was contaminated with Abestos. (Newswires)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – The bank is to name David Solomon CEO early this week and could be announced as soon as Monday. (NY Times)

S&P500

  • Arconic (ARNC) – Apollo (APO) and other private equity firms expressed interest in acquiring the engineering company. in a deal that could be worth more than USD 10bln, according to people familiar with the matter. Separately, the co. signed a multiyear contract with Boeing (BA) for the supply of aluminium sheet and plate and is to collaborate with Lockheed martin (LMT) on 3D printing and advanced aerospace materials. (WSJ/Newswires)
  • Brown-Forman (BF.B) – The co. announced a USD 200mln share repurchase programme. (Newswires)
  • Fortune Brands (FBHS) – The co. increases its share repurchase programme by USD 400mln. (Newswires)
  • General Electric (GE) – The head of GE aviation said the overhaul is not a constraint for the aviation arm, and believes it is the opposite. (Newswires)
  • J.M. Smucker (SJM) – The co. raises quarterly dividend by 9% to USD 0.85/shr. (Newswires)
  • L3 Technologies (LLL) – The co. appointed Stephen O'Bryan SVP and Chief Global Business Development Office. Separately, it is investing more than USD 100mln in the UK commercial aviation industry. (Newswires)
  • Lockheed Martin (LMT) – The US Pentagon has entered into a preliminary agreement to buy F-35 jets from the co. for approx. USD 13bln.  Separately, the defence group was selected by the US Space Agency for the development of a commercial seaport. (Newswires)
  • Northrop Grumman (NOC) – The defence contractor is positive on the possible sale of its drone system Triton MQ-4C to Germany which could take a few years to complete. The German government was said to be in talks with the US Navy after the State Department authorised the sale of 4 drones for approx. USD 2.5bln. (Newswires)
  • Parker Hanninf (PH) – Parker Aerospace, a unit of the co., has signed an agreement over a Gas Turbine Fuel Systems Division with GKN Aerospace Sweden. (Newswires)
  • Raytheon (RTN) – The defence name announced its StormBreaker bomb has now begun its operational testing phase, which brings it closer to providing US Air Force pilots, which will make them capable to hit moving targets in extreme weather conditions. (Newswires)
  • Scana (SCG) – The co. expanded the size of its board by adding two members and formed a special litigation committee. (Newswires)
  • Steel & Aluminium names (X, AKS, NUE, STLD, AA, CENX, CLF) – China has raised complaints at the WTO over the proposed USD 200bln tariffs. (Newswires)
  • United Technologies (UTX) – UTC Aerospace Systems, a unit of the co., was awarded a contract to upgrade C-130 propellers for 24 Lockheed Martin (LMT) C/KC-130T aircraft for the U.S. Navy's Naval Air Systems Command. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s positive on utility stocks such as American Electric Power (AEP), NextEra Energy (NEE) and Xcel Energy (XEL).
  • Barron’s reported Bill Ackman' may be coming back after being battered by a long position in Valeant Pharmaceuticals International (VRX) and a short one against Herbalife Nutrition (HLF), both closed out.
  • Barron’s said Broadcom (AVGO) is testing investors’ faith after announcing the USD 19bln acquisition of CA (CA).
  • Barron’s said the new Apple (AAPL) iPhone generation may introduce a chip called ‘eSIM’ which may have implications for AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ), Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS).

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon (AMZN) – The co.’s share of US e-commerce market is now at 49% as it is expected to clear USD 258.22bln in US retail sales. Amazon’s Prime Day also begins on Monday 1500 EDT, running through Tuesday. (TechCrunch)
  • Facebook (FB)/Alphabet (GOOGL)/Twitter (TWTR) – The two tech giants are to testify at a US House hearing on Tuesday on whether they are filtering information for political reasons. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media was criticised by the UK Information Commissioner for not acting to prevent the privacy scandal with Cambridge Analytica. (The Guardian)

OTHER NEWS

  • Papa John’s (PZZA) –The co.’s special committee has approved actions over founder John Schnatter and has agreed he will no longer have an active role in the co. following racist comments during a conference call. His image will be removed from any advertising campaign. The New York Yankees announced on Twitter to suspend their relationship with the co. "in response to the reprehensible remarks made by Papa John's founder and owner”. (Newswires)
  • Teva (TEVA) – The FDA launched a voluntary recall for several drugs containing valsartan for the treatment of high blood pressure and heart failure. (Newswires)
  • Wesco Aircraft (WAIR) – The co. renewed its multi-year agreement with BAE Systems (BA/ LN) for production of tails in the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter aircraft. (Newswires)
  • Embraer (ERJ) – United Airlines (UAL) announced the purchase of 25 new E-175 from Embraer (ERJ) and 4 new 787-9 aircrafts from Boeing (BA). (Newswires). ERJ anticipates demand for 10,550 smaller jets in next 20 years to be worth around USD 600bln. (Newswires)
  • Compass Minerals International (CMP) – The Canadian union, Unifor, announced a tentative agreement has been reached with CMP to end a 12-week strike at a salt mine in Goderich, Ontario. (Newswires)
  • Ryder (R) – The co, raises quarterly dividend to USD 0.54/shr from USD 0.52/shr. (Newswires)

subject: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin says there are no blanket waivers on Iran sanctions, there's no grandfathering
content:
• US will consider exemptions in certain cases if countries cannot reduce on Iran oil purchases to zero
  • US wants to be careful in the wind down around energy markets as it reimposes sanctions on Iran
  • US has the ability to issue waivers, and that is something that Treasury and State will be doing on Iran sanctions
  • Will discuss Iran sanctions with counterparts at G20 this week; allies have asked 'how we get there and timeline' for reimposing Iran sanctions

subject: Fixed and FX latest: small debt deviation and divergence, DXY down again
content: Not much more movement in core bonds, but Bunds inched a few ticks close to last Friday’s intraday base earlier, at 162.71 (-28 ticks vs -1 tick at the other extreme, while Gilts rebounded to a marginal new high on Liffe at 123.22 (+2 ticks vs -18 ticks at worst) in contrast, but have drifted back into negative territory again. In truth, its still somewhat aimless in debt markets vs FX where the Dollar lose a bit more momentum across the board as Eur/Usd firms up to 1.1725, Cable creeps back up towards 1.3300 and Usd/Jpy retreats from 112.55. Consequently, the DXY has lost 94.500 and slipped just below a few support levels, like a 50% Fib (94.770), its 10 DMA (94.458) and 30 DMA (94.431) to sit just above 94.400, awaiting some fundamental direction via early US data – Empire State manufacturing and retail sales.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 16th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Chinese GDP topped estimates on a Q/Q basis at 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.6%, but GDP Y/Y slowed in-line with forecasts to 6.7% vs. Prev. 6.8%
  • European equities (Eurostoxx 50 +0.1%) trade with little in the way of firm direction. Deutsche Bank prelim results lift financials
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US retail sales, NY Fed mfg, US President Trump meets with Russian President Putin

 

ASIA

Asian stocks began the week subdued with the region lacklustre amid the absence of Japanese participants and following a quiet weekend in terms of newsflow, while the region also digested a deluge of mixed Chinese data including a slowdown in Q2 GDP. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was on the backfoot from early trade amid cautiousness prior to the key Chinese releases and with the index dragged by losses in miners and financials. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) and Hang Seng (+0.1%) were initially downbeat after the mixed data in which GDP topped estimates on a Q/Q basis at 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.6%, but GDP Y/Y slowed inline with forecasts to 6.7% vs. Prev. 6.8%. In addition, Retail Sales was better than expected and Industrial Production disappointed, while the lending and money supply data late last week was also varied and added to the uninspired tone. In terms of today’s notable movers, ZTE shares surged after the US confirmed to lift the ban on US sales to the Co. while Xiaomi were on the other side of the spectrum after the Shanghai Stock Exchange banned investors from trading in a dozen of foreign companies and firms with weighted-voting rights via the stock-connect.

Chinese Premier Li reiterated China and EU are to uphold multilateralism and free trade during meeting with EU officials, while EU's Tusk said trade wars can result to hot conflicts and that EU is seeking support for WTO reform. (Newswires)

China Commerce Ministry says that China filed a complaint to WTO regarding the US proposed tariff list on USD 200bln worth of Chinese goods. (Newswires)

Chinese investors are to be banned from trading in shares of a dozen foreign firms and firms with weighted voting rights, as China aims to protect retail investors using HK link from less understood securities. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 170bln via 7-day and CNY 130bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net CNY 300bln daily injection. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6758 (Prev. 6.6727)

Chinese GDP (Q2) Q/Q 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.4%). (Newswires)

Chinese GDP (Q2) Y/Y 6.7% vs. Exp. 6.7% (Prev. 6.8%)

Chinese GDP YTD (Q2) Y/Y 6.8% vs. Exp. 6.7% (Prev. 6.8%)

Chinese Industrial Output (Jun) Y/Y 6.0% vs. Exp. 6.5% (Prev. 6.8%)

Chinese Retail Sales (Jun) Y/Y 9.0% vs. Exp. 8.8% (Prev. 8.5%)

EU/UK/US

US President Trump stated that he thinks the EU are a foe regarding what it does to the US on trade, while Trump also stated that China is a foe economically and that Russia is a foe in certain respects. (Newswires)

Eurosceptics have set up a “party within a party” with a highly organised whipping operation among Tory Eurosceptic MPs to try to frustrate Theresa May’s Brexit plans. (Telegraph)

UK PM May’s chances of winning support for her Brexit compromise have been dealt a huge blow as Justine Greening has become the first senior Conservative to support calls for a second referendum. (Times)

BBC journalist tweets "Am hearing the Govt could accept all the Brexiteer / ERG amendments to the Customs Bill". (Twitter)

An editor at PoliticsHome tweeted “Tory Brexiteer MP says they are not sure can get the 48 letters to force a vote of no confidence in Theresa May. And even if they did, chances are she would win and be untouchable for at least a year.”. (Twitter)

ECB’s Weidmann warned the German cabinet to be prepared for tougher times ahead during a meeting earlier this month and stated that the ECB has little scope to act in a slowdown due to policy normalisation. (Handelsblatt)

US rejected calls from the EU to grant exemptions to European companies from Iran sanctions. (Newswires)

US President Trump stated over the weekend that he fully intends to run for re-election in 2020. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities opened relatively flat and since then have traded in no firm direction (Eurostoxx 50 +0.1%). Financials (+0.7%) outperform as Deutsche Bank (+6.5%) ignited a bid in the sector after announcing better than expected Q2 preliminary results. Banks dominate gains in their respective bourses. Meanwhile, Indivior (+27.1%) shares sky-rocketed after a US court blocked Indian competitors from selling a cut-price version of Indivior’s bestselling opioid addiction treatment in the US. Due to the Farnborough Air Show, it may be worth keeping an eye on BAE Systems (BA/ LN), Rolls-Royce (RR/ LN), Leonardo (LDO IM), Boeing (BA) and Airbus (AIR FP).

FIXED INCOME

UK bonds have returned to Liffe lower in line with core counterparts and are testing bids/support ahead of the 123.00 handle within a 123.02-21 range vs last Friday’s 123.30 close after a fleeting uptick at the open. Indeed, Bunds have breached a downside technical area from 162.87-82 having respected near term resistance around 162.98 earlier, and slipped to a fresh 162.71 Eurex low that exposes last Friday’s 162.66 session base, while US Treasuries have ticked down to marginal new overnight troughs with the curve re-steepening a tad. Back to Liffe, the 3 month STIR strip is outperforming and 1-2 ticks above parity ahead of a run of major data starting on Tuesday, and amidst reports that the Government may yield to pressure from Brexiteers and agree to ERG amendments to the customs bill.

FX

DXY - The index is meandering within a narrow 94.558-776 band in line with restrained Dollar movement vs its G10 counterparts after last week’s volatile trade and relatively big swings culminated in the Usd netting decent gains, with the DXY briefly over 95.000 at one stage on Friday. Ahead, some data to provide impetus in the form of retail sales.

JPY - A marginal underperformer after suffering heaviest losses vs the Usd of late and closing below a key 76.4% Fib (112.33) on Friday, However, the absence of Japanese participants due to the Marine Day holiday has impacted trade overnight between 112.20-55.

CHF - Back on a par with the Greenback and still straddling 1.1700 vs the Eur, awaiting the next moves in global trade/tariff wars and anything from Trump’s meeting with Putin.

NZD/AUD - The Kiwi is just about shading it down under and firmly back above 0.6750 vs the Usd ahead of NZ inflation data tonight which is expected to reveal a firmer Q2 CPI y/y rate, while its antipodean counterpart is also extending recover gains vs the Usd over 0.7400, but could be hampered by heavy option expiry interest at the strike this week (3 bn) plus RBA minutes on Tuesday from this month’s policy meeting that was more dovish on balance.

EUR/GBP - Aside from generally lacklustre trade, the single currency could be caught up in option-related flows within 1.1650-1.1700 parameters given over 3 bn expiries in that range running off today. Moreover, the Eur may be drawn to a 1.2 bn expiry vs the Gbp at 0.8800 even though the Pound faces further Brexit risk via the Commons debate and vote on the Customs Bill later. Eur/Gbp currently around 0.8825 and Cable circa 1.3250 with key resistance capping the upside (30 DMA at 1.3260 and 61.8% Fib at 1.3263), while near term support for the latter comes in at 1.3236 (10 DMA).

CAD - The Loonie is pretty level vs its US peer and pivoting 1.3150 ahead of some Canadian data that could impact and/or offset any Usd-led moves in the form of existing home sales.

COMMODITIES

Commodities trade fairly mixed while WTI and Brent continue to leak with losses. Brent has broken below USD 75.00/bbl while WTI has taken out USD 70.00/bbl to the downside in the aftermath of a pullback from last Friday’s settlement amid reports that the Trump administration was said to be considering tapping into the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to rein in prices. Sentiment also hampered by the weekly Baker Hughes rig count showing an increase of 2 rigs in operation compared to the prior week. Meanwhile, in talks with the Saudi’s Energy Minister, Iranian Oil Minister said OPEC decision does not give members the right to raise their production level above targets

Elsewhere, gold (+0.2%) prices are buoyed by the softer USD. London Copper slipped this morning while Chinese Q2 growth printed a slight downtick (yet in-line with expectations), focus continues to remain on China’s response to US tariffs. Steel-linked metals, Nickel and Zinc, are subdued on lower demand expectations amid China’s top steelmaking city ordering steel mills to shut sintering plants for five days due to adverse weather conditions.

Iran warns OPEC it will be less effective if the production cap slip. (Newswires)

subject: Russia raises Sokol crude oil exports from Sakhalin-1 to 260K-266K BPD in Q3 (from 215K BPD in Q2)
analysis_details:
Sakhalin-1 is an international consortium project comprised of the following participants:

  • Exxon Neftegas Limited, a subsidiary of U.S.-based ExxonMobil, is the operator and holds a 30 percent interest;
  • Russian oil company Rosneft acting via its affiliates RN-Astra (8.5 percent) and Sakhalinmorneftegas-Shelf (11.5 percent);
  • Japanese consortium SODECO holds a 30 percent interest; and
  • Indian state-owned oil company ONGC Videsh Ltd. has 20 percent.

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures: mixed start to Monday’s session
content: UK bonds have returned to Liffe lower in line with core counterparts and are testing bids/support ahead of the 123.00 handle within a 123.02-21 range vs last Friday’s 123.30 close after a fleeting uptick at the open. Indeed, Bunds have breached a downside technical area from 162.87-82 having respected near term resistance around 162.98 earlier, and slipped to a fresh 162.77 Eurex low that exposes last Friday’s 162.66 session base, while US Treasuries have ticked down to marginal new overnight troughs with the curve re-steepening a tad. Back to Liffe, the 3 month STIR strip is outperforming and 1-2 ticks above parity ahead of a run of major data starting on Tuesday, and amidst reports that the Government may yield to pressure from Brexiteers and agree to ERG amendments to the customs bill.

analysis_details: • This could be indicative of PM May caving to the demands of her party and thus could pave the way for a harder Brexit than the one proposed by the White Paper last week.

ECB says banks borrowed EUR 134mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 668.277bln; excess liquidity EUR 1.868tln

EU takes note of China’s commitments to improve market access and intellectual property rights
Iran warns OPEC it will be less effective if the production cap slip
Bunds: hovering just below 163.00 after false break
content: The 10 year German debt future has drifted back a bit further from Friday’s peak in relatively lacklustre trade at the start of the new week, ranging between 162.87-97 vs the 162.98 previous Eurex close. The mildly softer tone reflects a similar dip in US Treasuries after hefty gains towards the end of last week that were partly US data related, but also positional amidst heightened US-China/global trade tensions and with Eurone bonds also deriving some independent support from dovish leaning ECB minutes/policy guidance vs ‘sources’ suggesting a split on the timing of a first rate hike. Ahead, not much on Monday’s regional agenda bar Italian and pan-Eurozone trade, but the US docket includes retail sales that is always erratic and therefore often market-moving.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

16th July 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks began the week subdued with the region lacklustre amid the absence of Japanese participants and following a quiet weekend in terms of newsflow, while the region also digested a deluge of mixed Chinese data including a slowdown in Q2 GDP. ASX 200 (-0.5%) was on the backfoot from early trade amid cautiousness prior to the key Chinese releases and with the index dragged by losses in miners and financials. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) and Hang Seng (-0.1%) were downbeat after the mixed data in which GDP topped estimates on a Q/Q basis at 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.6%, but GDP Y/Y slowed inline with forecasts to 6.7% vs. Prev. 6.8%. In addition, Retail Sales was better than expected and Industrial Production disappointed, while the lending and money supply data late last week was also varied and added to the uninspired tone. In terms of today’s notable movers, ZTE shares surged after the US confirmed to lift the ban on US sales to the Co. while Xiaomi were on the other side of the spectrum after the Shanghai Stock Exchange banned investors from trading in a dozen of foreign companies and firms with weighted-voting rights via the stock-connect.

FTSE

Unilever (ULVR LN) – Co. and the Leverhulme Trust are discussing union of the Co.’s legal structure into a single Netherland-based entity. (Sky News)

Sky (SKY LN) - Amazon is preparing the next phase of its pay-TV attack on the Co. with plans to unleash its own smart television set and elbow its way into more homes. (Telegraph)

Rolls Royce (RR/ LN) – Co. are set to offer maintenance credits to airlines affected by the 787 groundings, according to reports. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Debenhams  (DEB LN) - is under fresh pressure after it emerged credit insurers have reduced cover for suppliers to the department store chain in the latest sign of the challenges facing Britain’s high streets. (Guardian)

Indivior (INDV LN) – Co. was granted a preliminary injunction by a US court which blocks India’s  Dr Reddy’s Laboratories (DRRD IN) from selling cut-price versions of Indivior’s bestselling opioid addiction treatment in the US. (Newswires)

Virgin Money (VM/ LN) - CYBG are reportedly considering raising its offer for the Co. after the BoE raised the Co.’s core capital ratio to around 16%. (Newswires)

Stagecoach (SGC LN)/National Express (NEX LN) – HSBC is cautions for rail in the second half of this year. (Newswires)

Defence Names - UK PM May is to promise extra investment for the aerospace industry just days after Airbus threatened to reduce its UK presence because of Brexit disruption. (BBC)

UK Pension Names – MPs have called on the government to “move quickly” to enable a new type of retirement scheme to be available in the UK, claiming it can potentially offer “better pensions” to millions of workers. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

AA (AA/ LN) DOWNGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

MICRO FOCUS (MCRO LN) DOWNGRADED OT UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY) – The co. wins a ruling against Mylan (MYL) challenge Xarelto patent. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. wants to strengthen its position in payment positions with fintech company takeovers; according to the Co.’s head of transaction banking. (Handelsblatt)

Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) – The largest shareholders of the Co. and KONE (KNEBV FH) have held talks on a potential merger of the elevator businesses of both companies. (Handelsblatt)  

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) – Co.’s T-Systems is losing the maintenance contract for PC workplaces at RWE (RWE GY) and Innogy (IGY GY). (WiWo)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Dialog Semiconductors (DLG GY) – The co. expects higher profitability than anticipated in Q2 2018. Preliminary Q2 gross margin up slightly vs. Q1. (Newswires)

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Co. is said to be closing in on USD 29bln of deals with Asian carriers looking to expand their fleet. (Newswires)

Safran (SAF FP) – The aircraft engine maker CFM is confident it will meet delivery targets this year. CFM is a JV between General Electric (GE) and Safran. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

LAGARDERE (MMB FP) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

ELISA (ELISA FH) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – Co. has received FDA clearance for the expanded use of its Elecsys B.R.A.H.M.S PCT Assay. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

Santander (SAN SM) – Cerberus have reportedly made an offer for the Co.’s property assets. (Newswires)

US

* SPX +0.1% at 2801.20, NDX +0.1% at 7375.8, DJI +0.4% at 25018. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +0.6%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.3%, Energy: +0.56%, Financials: -0.5%, Health Care: +0.2%, Industrials: +0.6%, Materials: 0.0%, Telecoms: -0.8%, Tech: 0.0%, Utilities: +0.1%.

The SPX hit a five-month high in early trade with the DJI breaking above 25,000 for the first time in over a month before paring back later in the session.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 16th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks began the week subdued. Chinese GDP beat on a Q/Q basis, in-line Y/Y, retail sales a beat, industrial production a miss
  • UK Eurosceptics have set up a “party within a party” with a highly organised whipping operation among Tory Eurosceptic MPs. Justine Greening calls for a second referendum
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US retail sales, NY Fed mfg, US President Trump meets with Russian President Putin

ASIA

Asian stocks began the week subdued with the region lacklustre amid the absence of Japanese participants and following a quiet weekend in terms of newsflow, while the region also digested a deluge of mixed Chinese data including a slowdown in Q2 GDP. ASX 200 (-0.5%) was on the backfoot from early trade amid cautiousness prior to the key Chinese releases and with the index dragged by losses in miners and financials. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) and Hang Seng (-0.1%) were downbeat after the mixed data in which GDP topped estimates on a Q/Q basis at 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.6%, but GDP Y/Y slowed inline with forecasts to 6.7% vs. Prev. 6.8%. In addition, Retail Sales was better than expected and Industrial Production disappointed, while the lending and money supply data late last week was also varied and added to the uninspired tone. In terms of today’s notable movers, ZTE shares surged after the US confirmed to lift the ban on US sales to the Co. while Xiaomi were on the other side of the spectrum after the Shanghai Stock Exchange banned investors from trading in a dozen of foreign companies and firms with weighted-voting rights via the stock-connect.

Chinese Premier Li reiterated China and EU are to uphold multilateralism and free trade during meeting with EU officials, while EU's Tusk said trade wars can result to hot wars and that EU is seeking support for WTO reform. (Newswires)


Chinese investors are to be banned from trading in shares of a dozen foreign firms and firms with weighted voting rights, as China aims to protect retail investors using HK link from less understood securities. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 170bln via 7-day and CNY 130bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net CNY 300bln daily injection. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6758 (Prev. 6.6727)

Chinese GDP (Q2) Q/Q 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.4%). (Newswires)
Chinese GDP (Q2) Y/Y 6.7% vs. Exp. 6.7% (Prev. 6.8%)
Chinese GDP YTD (Q2) Y/Y 6.8% vs. Exp. 6.7% (Prev. 6.8%)

Chinese Industrial Output (Jun) Y/Y 6.0% vs. Exp. 6.5% (Prev. 6.8%)

Chinese Retail Sales (Jun) Y/Y 9.0% vs. Exp. 8.8% (Prev. 8.5%)

UK

Eurosceptics have set up a “party within a party” with a highly organised whipping operation among Tory Eurosceptic MPs to try to frustrate Theresa May’s Brexit plans. (Telegraph)

UK PM May’s chances of winning support for her Brexit compromise have been dealt a huge blow as Justine Greening has become the first senior Conservative to support calls for a second referendum. (Times)

UK PM May has been dealt a further blow after Robert Courts, who replaced David Cameron as Tory MP for Witney, has quit as a ministerial aide at the Foreign Office to oppose the Chequers proposals. (Times)

Brexit Secretary Raab is stepping up preparations for a “no deal” Brexit and expanding the government unit that is preparing for the possibility of Britain crashing out of the EU. (FT)

Conservative Tory chairman Lewis has been accused of threatening to cut funding from Brexiteer opponents of Chequers deal. (Telegraph)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Jul) M/M 0.1% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)
UK Rightmove House Prices (Jul) Y/Y 1.4% (Prev. 1.7%)
UK Visa Consumer Spending in June rose by 0.7% Y/Y (Prev. 0.9%); first consecutive increase in over a year.


EU

US President Trump stated that he thinks the EU are a foe regarding what it does to the US on trade, while Trump also stated that China is a foe economically and that Russia is a foe in certain respects. (Newswires)
 

ECB’s Weidmann warned the German cabinet to be prepared for tougher times ahead during a meeting earlier this month and stated that the ECB has little scope to act in a slowdown due to policy normalisation. (Handelsblatt)

Fitch affirmed Spain at 'A-'; Outlook Stable and downgraded Turkey from BB+ to BB; outlook negative. (Fitch Ratings)
 

FX

FX markets were quiet overnight in which most majors remained near Friday’s close and the DXY consolidated after it failed to hold on to the 95.00 level last week. This kept EUR/USD and GBP/USD sideways at the 1.1600 and 1.3200 handles respectively to provide some early respite from last week’s tumultuous price swings. Elsewhere, JPY-crosses were also indecisive amid the absence of Japanese participants, while commodity linked currencies saw a minimal pullback overnight after the somewhat inconclusive Chinese data.
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded flat overnight with WTI crude futures heading into European trade lower 0.6% and back below the USD 71.00/bbl level with the downtick the result of a pullback from last Friday’s settlement amid reports that the Trump administration was said to be considering tapping into the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to rein in prices. Elsewhere, gold was little changed with minimal gains seen following last Friday’s pull back in the USD, while copper also traded sideways as demand was restricted by a lacklustre tone in the region and mixed Chinese data.

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (13 Jul) 1054 (Prev. 1052). (Newswires)

Trump Administration was reported on Friday to be considering tapping the US emergency oil reserve (SPR), with the size said to be between a 5mln barrel test up to 30mln barrels. (Newswires)

Norwegian oil and gas strike escalated in which with the union added a further 900 workers after the deadline passed with no agreement reached. (Newswires)

US rejected calls from the EU to grant exemptions to European companies from Iran sanctions. (Newswires)


US

Treasuries held in positive ground on Friday amid decent volume on the buy side heading into the weekend and supported by marginal flow factors coming from Europe and Japan. Most of the action was concentrated in the belly of the curve where yields were lower by c.2bps. Spread were mixed as 2s5s and 2s10s narrowed by c.1bps whilst 5s30s widened by c.1bps. US 10YR T-notes futures (U8) settled 6+ ticks higher at 120.11+.

US President Trump stated over the weekend that he fully intends to run for re-election in 2020. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) said intensifications of trade tariffs would see downgrades to 2018 and 2019 growth forecasts, while he also said that he expects one more hike in 2018 and could be convinced of a fourth hike depending on outlook. (Newswires)
